Calculation of Araki-Sucher correction for many-electron systems

Justyna G. Balcerzak    Michał Lesiuk e-mail: lesiuk@tiger.chem.uw.edu.pl    Robert Moszynski Faculty of Chemistry, University of Warsaw
Pasteura 1, 02-093 Warsaw, Poland
Abstract

In this paper we consider the evaluation of the Araki-Sucher correction for arbitrary many-electron atomic and molecular systems. This contribution appears in the leading order quantum electrodynamics corrections to the energy of a bound state. The conventional one-electron basis set of Gaussian-type orbitals (GTOs) is adopted; this leads to two-electron matrix elements which are evaluated with help of generalised the McMurchie-Davidson scheme. We also consider the convergence of the results towards the complete basis set. A rigorous analytic result for the convergence rate is obtained and verified by comparing with independent numerical values for the helium atom. Finally, we present a selection of numerical examples and compare our results with the available reference data for small systems. In contrast with other methods used for the evaluation of the Araki-Sucher correction, our method is not restricted to few-electron atoms or molecules. This is illustrated by calculations for several many-electron atoms and molecules.

31.15.vn, 03.65.Ge, 02.30.Gp, 02.30.Hq

I Introduction

In the past few decades there has been remarkable a progress in the many-body electronic structure theory. This has allowed to treat large systems of chemical or biological significance containing hundreds of electrons and, at the same time, obtain very accurate results for small systems which are intensively studied spectroscopically. Introduction of general explicitly correlated methods hattig12 ; kong12 ; tenno12 , reliable extrapolation techniques helgaker97 ; halkier98 ; halkier99a ; halkier99b ; halkier99c ; truhlar98 , general coupled cluster theories kallay01 ; hirata03 , and new or improved one-electron basis sets dunning89 ; woon95 ; peterson02 ; kemmish14 ; kemmish15a ; kemmish15b ; lesiuk12 ; lesiuk14a ; lesiuk14b ; lesiuk15 ; lesiuk16 made the so-called spectroscopic accuracy (few cm-1 or less) achievable for many small molecules.

However, as the accuracy standards of routine calculations are tightened up one encounters new challenges. One of these challenges is the necessity to include corrections due to finite mass of the nuclei born56 , relativistic, and quantum electrodynamic (QED) effects bethe75 , and possibly finite nuclear size vissher97 . The former two have been subjects to many studies in the past decades, see Refs. kolos64 ; wolniewicz93 ; kutz97 ; valeev03 ; gauss06 ; pykko78 ; dyall07 ; reiher09 and references therein. However, systematic studies of importance of the QED effects in atoms and molecules are scarce and have begun relatively recently beier05 ; kozhedub08 ; pasteka17 . High accuracy of the ab initio calculations and reliability of the theoretical predictions is of prime importance, e.g., in the field of ultracold molecules. This is best illustrated by the papers of McGuyer et al. mcguyer15 devoted to observation of the subradiant states of Sr2 or by McDonald and collaborators mcdonald16 where photodissociation of ultracold molecules was studied. Notably, the importance of QED effects has also been realised in the first-principles studies of He2 for the purposes of metrology jeziorski10 ; jeziorski12 ; jeziorski17 .

QED is definitely one of the most successful theories in physics, with calculation of the anomalous magnetic moment of the electron being the prime example kinoshita06 ; hagiwara07 ; aoyama12 . However, applications to the bound states, e.g., with a strong Coulomb field are marred with problems. Two physical phenomena, electron self-energy and vacuum polarisation, giving rise to the Lamb shift bethe75 are difficult to include in the standard many-body theories. For moderate and large Z𝑍Z approaches based on the Uehling potential uehling35 with optional corrections wichmann56 ; blomqvist72 , scaling of the hydrogen-like values johnson85 ; mohr92 , effective potentials of Shabaev et al. shabaev02 ; shabaev03 , multiple commutator approach by Labzowsky and Goidenko labzowski97 ; labzowski99 , and effective Hamiltonians of Flambaum and Ginges flambaum05 were used with a considerable success.

However, for small and moderate Z𝑍Z the most theoretically consistent approach is the nonrelativistic QED theory (NRQED) proposed by Caswell and Lepage caswell86 and further developed and extended by Pachucki pachucki93 ; pachucki98 ; pachucki04a ; pachucki05 . This method relies on the expansion of the exact energy in power series of the fine structure constant, α𝛼\alpha. The coefficients of the expansion are evaluated as expectation values of an effective Hamiltonian with the nonrelativistic wavefunction. Thus, the zeroth-order term is simply the nonrelativistic energy, the first-order term is zero, the second-order contributions are expectation values of the Breit-Pauli Hamiltonian (the relativistic corrections).

NRQED has been successfully applied to numerous few-electron atomic and molecular systems. Obvious applications are the one-electron systems such as hydrogen-like atoms (see Ref. sapirstein90 for a comprehensive review) and hydrogen molecular ion bishop81 ; bukowski92 ; korobov04 ; korobov06 ; korobov13 . Beyond that, very accurate results are available for the helium atom schwartz61 ; yan98 ; korobov99 ; drake99 ; cencek01 ; pachucki00a ; pachucki00b ; pachucki06a ; pachucki06c ; lach04 ; pachucki17a ; pachucki17b , hydrogen molecule garcia66 ; bishop78 ; wolniewicz95 ; kpisz09 ; komasa11 ; puchalski16 , and their isotopomers. Remarkably, corrections of the order α4superscript𝛼4\alpha^{4} have been derived and evaluated recently pachucki06a ; pachucki06b ; puchalski16 ; pachucki10b . Other examples are lithium yan02 ; pachucki03 ; puchalski13a and beryllium atoms puchalski13b with the corresponding ions pachucki06b , and helium dimer jeziorski10 ; jeziorski12 ; cencek12 . In all these examples very accurate agreement with the experimental data has been obtained which confirms validity and applicability of NRQED to light molecular and atomic systems. However, all presently available rigorous methods for calculation of the NRQED corrections are inherently limited to few-body systems and cannot be straightforwardly extended to larger ones.

In the framework of NRQED, the leading (pure) QED corrections are of the order α3superscript𝛼3\alpha^{3} and α3​ln⁡αsuperscript𝛼3𝛼\alpha^{3}\ln\alpha. For a singlet atomic or molecular state one has araki57 ; sucher58

E(3)=8​α3​π​(1930−2​ln⁡α−ln⁡k0)​⟨D1⟩+απ​(16415+143​ln⁡α)​⟨D2⟩+⟨HA​S⟩,superscript𝐸38𝛼3𝜋19302𝛼subscript𝑘0delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐷1𝛼𝜋16415143𝛼delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐷2delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐻𝐴𝑆\displaystyle\begin{split}E^{(3)}&=\frac{8\alpha}{3\pi}\left(\frac{19}{30}-2\ln\alpha-\ln k_{0}\right)\langle D_{1}\rangle\\ &+\frac{\alpha}{\pi}\left(\frac{164}{15}+\frac{14}{3}\ln\alpha\right)\langle D_{2}\rangle+\langle H_{AS}\rangle,\end{split} (1)

where ln⁡k0subscript𝑘0\ln k_{0} is the so-called Bethe logarithm bethe75 ; schwartz61 ; ⟨D1⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐷1\langle D_{1}\rangle and ⟨D2⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐷2\langle D_{2}\rangle are the one- and two-electron Darwin terms

⟨D2⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐷2\displaystyle\langle D_{2}\rangle =π​α2​⟨∑i>jδ​(ri​j)⟩,absent𝜋superscript𝛼2delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝑖𝑗𝛿subscriptr𝑖𝑗\displaystyle=\pi\,\alpha^{2}\,\langle\sum_{i>j}\delta(\textbf{r}_{ij})\rangle, (3)

where Zasubscript𝑍𝑎Z_{a} are the nuclear charges, and δ​(𝐫)𝛿𝐫\delta(\mathbf{r}) is the three-dimensional Dirac delta distribution. Throughout the paper, we use letters i,j,…𝑖𝑗…i,j,\ldots and a,b,…𝑎𝑏…a,b,\ldots to denote summations over electrons and nuclei, respectively. The last term in Eq. (1) is the Araki-Sucher correction

⟨HA​S⟩=−7​α36​π​⟨∑i>jP^​(ri​j−3)⟩,delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐻𝐴𝑆7superscript𝛼36𝜋delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝑖𝑗^𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑗3\displaystyle\langle H_{AS}\rangle=-\frac{7\alpha^{3}}{6\pi}\langle\sum_{i>j}\hat{P}\left(r_{ij}^{-3}\right)\rangle, (4)

where the regularised distribution in the brackets is defined by the following formulae

P^​(ri​j−3)=lima→0P^a​(ri​j−3),^𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑗3subscript→𝑎0subscript^𝑃𝑎superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑗3\displaystyle\hat{P}(r_{ij}^{-3})=\lim_{a\rightarrow 0}\hat{P}_{a}(r_{ij}^{-3}), (5)

and

P^a​(ri​j−3)=θ​(ri​j−a)​ri​j−3+4​π​(γ+ln⁡a)​δ​(𝐫i​j),subscript^𝑃𝑎superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑗3𝜃subscript𝑟𝑖𝑗𝑎superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑗34𝜋𝛾𝑎𝛿subscript𝐫𝑖𝑗\displaystyle\hat{P}_{a}(r_{ij}^{-3})=\theta(r_{ij}-a)\,r_{ij}^{-3}+4\pi\left(\gamma+\ln a\right)\delta(\mathbf{r}_{ij}), (6)

where γ𝛾\gamma is the Euler–Mascheroni constant, and θ​(x)𝜃𝑥\theta(x) is the Heaviside step function in the usual convention.

In evaluation of the QED corrections for many-electron atoms and molecules, two quantities present in Eq. (1) are the major source of difficulties. The first one is the Bethe logarithm and the second is the Araki-Sucher correction. In this paper we are concerned with the latter quantity; evaluation of the Bethe logarithm will be considered in subsequent papers. Let us point out that the Araki-Sucher term is not necessarily the largest of the α3superscript𝛼3\alpha^{3} QED corrections. In fact, the one-electron terms typically dominate in Eq. (1). However, the relative importance of the Araki-Sucher correction is expected to increase for heavier atoms similarly as for the two-electron terms of the Breit-Pauli Hamiltonian. Moreover, for polyatomic systems the Araki-Sucher correction possesses an usual R−3superscript𝑅3R^{-3} asymptotics for large interatomic distances, R𝑅R. As a result, it decays much less rapidly than the other components of the potential energy curve pachucki05b and its importance is substantial for large R𝑅R.

From the point of view of the many-body electronic structure theory Eq. (4) is an ordinary expectation value of a two-electron operator. Provided that the corresponding matrix elements are available, evaluation of such expectation values by using the coupled cluster (CC) bartlett07 or configuration interaction (CI) wavefunctions is a standard task salter89 ; hald03 ; coriani04 ; jeziorski93 ; moszynski05 ; korona06 ; tucholska14 ; tucholska17 . Therefore, in this work we are concerned with evaluation of the matrix elements (i.e., two-electron integrals) of the Araki-Sucher distribution in the Gaussian-type orbitals (GTOs) basis boys50 . Importantly, the proposed method can be applied to an arbitrary molecule and is not limited to few-electron systems.

Throughout the paper, we follow Ref. stegun72 in definitions of all special and elementary functions.

II Calculation of the matrix elements

In this section we consider evaluation of matrix elements necessary to calculate the Araki-Sucher correction for many-electron atomic and molecular systems. We adopt the usual Gaussian-type orbitals (GTOs) in the Cartesian representation boys50 as one-electron basis set

ϕa​(𝐫A)=xAi​yAk​zAm​e−a​rA2,subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑎subscript𝐫𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑥𝐴𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑦𝐴𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑧𝐴𝑚superscript𝑒𝑎superscriptsubscript𝑟𝐴2\phi_{a}(\mathbf{r}_{A})=x_{A}^{i}\,y_{A}^{k}\,z_{A}^{m}\,e^{-ar_{A}^{2}}, (7)

where 𝐀=(Ax,Ay,Az)𝐀subscript𝐴𝑥subscript𝐴𝑦subscript𝐴𝑧\mathbf{A}=(A_{x},A_{y},A_{z}) is a vector specifying location of the orbital, xA=x−Axsubscript𝑥𝐴𝑥subscript𝐴𝑥x_{A}=x-A_{x} and similarly for the remaining coordinates. For brevity, we omit the normalisation constant in the definition (7). However, normalised orbitals are used in all calculations described further in the paper.

Evaluation of the Araki-Sucher correction from the many-electron coupled cluster wavefunction within the basis set (7) requires the following two-electron matrix elements

(a​b|c​d)=∬d​𝐫1​d​𝐫2​ϕa​(𝐫1​A)​ϕb​(𝐫1​B)×P^​(r12−3)​ϕc​(𝐫2​C)​ϕd​(𝐫2​D).conditional𝑎𝑏𝑐𝑑double-integraldsubscript𝐫1dsubscript𝐫2subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑎subscript𝐫1𝐴subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑏subscript𝐫1𝐵^𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑟123subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑐subscript𝐫2𝐶subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑑subscript𝐫2𝐷\displaystyle\begin{split}\left(ab|cd\right)=\iint\text{d}\mathbf{r}_{1}\,\text{d}\mathbf{r}_{2}\,\phi_{a}(\mathbf{r}_{1A})\,\phi_{b}(\mathbf{r}_{1B})\\ \times\,\hat{P}(r_{12}^{-3})\,\phi_{c}(\mathbf{r}_{2C})\,\phi_{d}(\mathbf{r}_{2D}).\end{split} (8)

The scheme presented further in the paper relies on the McMurchie-Davidson method mcmurchie78 ; helgaker92 . This method was first introduced in the context of the standard two-electron repulsion integrals and various one-electron integrals necessary for calculation of the molecular properties. Later, it was extended to handle integral derivatives and more involved two-electron integrals found in the so-called explicitly correlated methods samson02 ; sila15 . While some other methods of calculation of the usual electron repulsion integrals are more computationally efficient (cf. Ref. gill94 ) than the McMurchie-Davidson scheme, the latter is much simpler to implement and extend to more complicated integrals. This was the main motivation for its use in the present context.

II.1 Generalised McMurchie-Davidson scheme

The backbone of the McMurchie-Davidson scheme is the so-called Gauss-Hermite function, Λt​(x;a)subscriptΛ𝑡𝑥𝑎\Lambda_{t}(x;a), defined formally as

Λt​(xA;a)​exp⁡(−a​xA2)=∂Axtexp⁡(−a​xA2).subscriptΛ𝑡subscript𝑥𝐴𝑎𝑎superscriptsubscript𝑥𝐴2superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐴𝑥𝑡𝑎superscriptsubscript𝑥𝐴2\displaystyle\Lambda_{t}(x_{A};a)\exp(-ax_{A}^{2})=\partial_{A_{x}}^{t}\exp(-ax_{A}^{2}). (9)

Clearly, the functions Λt​(x;a)subscriptΛ𝑡𝑥𝑎\Lambda_{t}(x;a) are closely related (by scaling) with the well-known Hermite polynomials. It is also straightforward to prove the following relation

Note that differentiation with respect to the coordinates of 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} in Eq. (12) has been replaced by differentiation with respect to the corresponding components of 𝐐𝐐\mathbf{Q}. This is valid because the basic integral is dependent only on the length of 𝐏−𝐐𝐏𝐐\mathbf{P}-\mathbf{Q} but not on the individual components.

The biggest inconvenience connected with Eq. (13) is the necessity to differentiate with respect to Cartesian coordinates. In the original treatment of McMurchie and Davidson (concerning the standard electron repulsion integrals) a four-dimensional recursion relation was introduced to resolve this issue mcmurchie78 ; helgaker92 . This approach is difficult to generalise to other basic integrals and typically requires a separate treatment in each case. In a recent paper we proposed a different strategy based on the following expression sila15

xt​yu​zv=∑l=0lm​a​x∑m=−llct​u​vl​m​rlm​a​x−l​Zl​m​(𝐫),superscript𝑥𝑡superscript𝑦𝑢superscript𝑧𝑣superscriptsubscript𝑙0subscript𝑙𝑚𝑎𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑙𝑙subscriptsuperscript𝑐𝑙𝑚𝑡𝑢𝑣superscript𝑟subscript𝑙𝑚𝑎𝑥𝑙subscript𝑍𝑙𝑚𝐫\displaystyle x^{t}y^{u}z^{v}=\sum_{l=0}^{l_{max}}\sum_{m=-l}^{l}c^{lm}_{tuv}\,r^{l_{max}-l}\,Z_{lm}(\mathbf{r}), (15)

The numerical coefficients ct​u​vl​msubscriptsuperscript𝑐𝑙𝑚𝑡𝑢𝑣c^{lm}_{tuv} can be precalculated and stored in memory as a look-up table (cf. the work of Schlegel schlegel95 ). In analogy, the differentials present in Eq. (13) are rewritten as

∂Qxt∂Qyu∂Qzv=∑l=0lm​a​x∑m=−llct​u​vl​m​∇Qlm​a​x−lZ^l​m​(∇Q),superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑄𝑥𝑡superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑄𝑦𝑢superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑄𝑧𝑣superscriptsubscript𝑙0subscript𝑙𝑚𝑎𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑙𝑙subscriptsuperscript𝑐𝑙𝑚𝑡𝑢𝑣superscriptsubscript∇𝑄subscript𝑙𝑚𝑎𝑥𝑙subscript^𝑍𝑙𝑚subscript∇𝑄\displaystyle\partial_{Q_{x}}^{t}\,\partial_{Q_{y}}^{u}\,\partial_{Q_{z}}^{v}=\sum_{l=0}^{l_{max}}\sum_{m=-l}^{l}c^{lm}_{tuv}\,\nabla_{Q}^{l_{max}-l}\,\hat{Z}_{lm}(\nabla_{Q}), (16)

where ∇Qsubscript∇𝑄\nabla_{Q} is the gradient operator and Z^l​m​(∇Q)subscript^𝑍𝑙𝑚subscript∇𝑄\hat{Z}_{lm}(\nabla_{Q}) are the (real) spherical harmonic gradient operators weniger05 . Heuristically, they are obtained by taking an explicit expression for Zl​m​(𝐫)subscript𝑍𝑙𝑚𝐫Z_{lm}(\mathbf{r}) and replacing all Cartesian coordinates with the corresponding differentials.

By the virtue of the Hobson theorem hobson92 one has

II.2 Basic integral and derivatives

One can easily prove that the infinite series present in the above expression is convergent for an arbitrary real ξ​Q2𝜉superscript𝑄2\xi Q^{2}. Therefore, this formula constitutes an exact analytical result. However, the rate of convergence of this series can be expected to be very slow for large values of the parameter, greatly increasing the cost of the calculations. Moreover, this representation does not allow for a straightforward calculation of the derivatives, DQlsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑄𝑙D_{Q}^{l}. Therefore, it is desirable to bring this expression into a more computationally convenient form.

For this sake, the series in Eq. (28) is summed analytically giving the following integral representation

∑n=1∞4n​(n−1)!(2​n+1)!​xn=∫01d​t​(1−t)1/2​et​x−1t.superscriptsubscript𝑛1superscript4𝑛𝑛12𝑛1superscript𝑥𝑛superscriptsubscript01d𝑡superscript1𝑡12superscript𝑒𝑡𝑥1𝑡\displaystyle\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\,\frac{4^{n}(n-1)!}{(2n+1)!}\,x^{n}=\int_{0}^{1}\text{d}t\,(1-t)^{1/2}\,\frac{e^{tx}-1}{t}. (29)

(30) is valid for an arbitrary complex-valued x𝑥x.

At this point we would like to compare our results with some other expressions published in the literature. An integral closely related to the basic integral B𝐵B was considered in Ref. kpisz09 . In fact, one can verify that by setting c1=c2=0subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐20c_{1}=c_{2}=0 in Eq. (15) of Ref. kpisz09 one obtains Eq. (14) of the present work (after taking the a→0→𝑎0a\rightarrow 0 limit). However, no results for the derivatives DQl​Bsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑄𝑙𝐵D_{Q}^{l}B were provided as they do not appear in the explicitly correlated Gaussian calculations. Interestingly, an alternative integral representation of J0​(x)subscript𝐽0𝑥J_{0}(x) was given in Ref. kpisz09 . In our notation

J0​(x)=e−x​∫0xd​tt​[πt​et2​erf​(t)−1],subscript𝐽0𝑥superscript𝑒𝑥superscriptsubscript0𝑥d𝑡𝑡delimited-[]𝜋𝑡superscript𝑒𝑡2erf𝑡1\displaystyle J_{0}(x)=e^{-x}\int_{0}^{x}\frac{\text{d}t}{t}\left[\sqrt{\frac{\pi}{t}}\frac{e^{t}}{2}\,\mbox{erf}(\sqrt{t})-1\right], (33)

where erf​(x)erf𝑥\mbox{erf}(x) is the error function. One can verify that the definitions (30) and (33) coincide by exchanging the variables and working out the inner integral. We have not found the above representation particularly useful in the present context, but it provides an additional verification that our final result is correct.

II.3 Auxiliary integrals Jl​(x)subscript𝐽𝑙𝑥J_{l}(x)

The only missing building block of the present theory is the calculation of the integrals Jl​(x)subscript𝐽𝑙𝑥J_{l}(x). First, let us specify the range of parameters (x𝑥x and l𝑙l) which are of interest. The maximal value of l𝑙l is set to 323232 in our program. This allows to compute the integrals (8) with the maximal value i+k+m=8𝑖𝑘𝑚8i+k+m=8 in the one-electron basis set, see Eq. (7). This corresponds to the maximal value of the angular momentum l=8𝑙8l=8 (L𝐿L-type functions) in a purely spherical representation. The are no limitations on the value of x≥0𝑥0x\geq 0, i.e., the code is open-ended with respect to positive values of x𝑥x. Below, we provide a set of procedures based mostly on the recursive relations which allow to calculate the integrals Jl​(x)subscript𝐽𝑙𝑥J_{l}(x) with accuracy of at least 12 significant digits over the whole range of parameters specified above.

First, for x=0𝑥0x=0 the integrals Jl​(x)subscript𝐽𝑙𝑥J_{l}(x) take a particularly simple analytic form

Jl​(0)=2−2​ln⁡2−Hl+1/2,subscript𝐽𝑙0222subscript𝐻𝑙12\displaystyle J_{l}(0)=2-2\ln 2-H_{l+1/2}, (34)

where Hnsubscript𝐻𝑛H_{n} are the harmonic numbers. This expression can be rewritten as a convenient recursion Jl+1​(0)=Jl​(0)−22​l+3subscript𝐽𝑙10subscript𝐽𝑙022𝑙3J_{l+1}(0)=J_{l}(0)-\frac{2}{2l+3}, starting with J0​(0)=0subscript𝐽000J_{0}(0)=0. The values of Jl​(0)subscript𝐽𝑙0J_{l}(0) constitute an important special case corresponding to the atomic integrals, but they appear in large numbers also in molecular calculations.

For any value of x𝑥x the integrals Jl​(x)subscript𝐽𝑙𝑥J_{l}(x) obey the following recursion relation

Jl+1​(x)=Jl​(x)−2​Fl+1​(x),subscript𝐽𝑙1𝑥subscript𝐽𝑙𝑥2subscript𝐹𝑙1𝑥\displaystyle J_{l+1}(x)=J_{l}(x)-2F_{l+1}(x), (35)

where

Fn​(T)=∫01d​t​t2​n​e−T​t2.subscript𝐹𝑛𝑇superscriptsubscript01d𝑡superscript𝑡2𝑛superscript𝑒𝑇superscript𝑡2\displaystyle\begin{split}F_{n}(T)&=\int_{0}^{1}\text{d}t\,t^{2n}\,e^{-Tt^{2}}.\end{split} (36)

The latter quantity is nothing but the famous Boys function boys50 considered countless number of times in the quantum chemistry literature (see, for example, Refs. gill91 ; ishida96 ; kara10 ; weiss15 and references therein). Accurate and efficient methods for calculation of Fn​(T)subscript𝐹𝑛𝑇F_{n}(T) are available and there is no reason for us to elaborate on this issue.

Returning to the recursion relation (35), its direct use is hampered by a peculiar behaviour of the integrals Jl​(x)subscript𝐽𝑙𝑥J_{l}(x). Let us temporarily consider l𝑙l to be a continuous variable. Then, for any fixed x>0𝑥0x>0 the integrals Jl​(x)subscript𝐽𝑙𝑥J_{l}(x) have a root as a function of l𝑙l. For brevity, let us call the exact position of the root (as a function of x𝑥x) the critical line, l0​(x)subscript𝑙0𝑥l_{0}(x). The exact location of the root cannot be obtained with elementary methods, but we found that a simple linear function

l0​(x)=0.44+1.17​xsubscript𝑙0𝑥0.441.17𝑥\displaystyle l_{0}(x)=0.44+1.17x (37)

provides a reasonably faithful picture. If the recursion (35) is carried out and the critical line is crossed, one can expect an unacceptable loss of significant digits due to the cancellations. Therefore, this simple approach is inherently numerically unstable, independently of whether the recursion is carried out upward or downward.

One of the possible solutions to this problem is to assert that the critical line is never crossed during the recursive process. This can be achieved as follows. For an interval of x𝑥x of approximately unit length we find the smallest value of l𝑙l above the critical line (lasubscript𝑙𝑎l_{a}) and the largest value of l𝑙l below the critical line (lbsubscript𝑙𝑏l_{b}). Starting from the value at lasubscript𝑙𝑎l_{a} the upward recursion is initiated and carried out up to the maximal desired value of l𝑙l. Similarly, the downward recursion is initiated at lbsubscript𝑙𝑏l_{b} and stopped at l=0𝑙0l=0. This guarantees that the integrals Jl​(x)subscript𝐽𝑙𝑥J_{l}(x) do not change sign in both sub-recursions and the whole process is completely numerically stable since the integrals Ml​(x)subscript𝑀𝑙𝑥M_{l}(x) are always positive.

The remaining problem is to evaluate the integrals Jl​(x)subscript𝐽𝑙𝑥J_{l}(x) at lasubscript𝑙𝑎l_{a} and lbsubscript𝑙𝑏l_{b} for a given x𝑥x. This is achieved by fitting Jla​(x)subscript𝐽subscript𝑙𝑎𝑥J_{l_{a}}(x) and Jlb​(x)subscript𝐽subscript𝑙𝑏𝑥J_{l_{b}}(x) for each interval of x𝑥x. Since the length of each interval is only about unity the ordinary exponential-polynomial foot1 fitting is sufficient, i.e.

e−x​∑k=0Nf​i​tck(1)​xk.superscript𝑒𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑘0subscript𝑁𝑓𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑘1superscript𝑥𝑘\displaystyle e^{-x}\sum_{k=0}^{N_{fit}}c_{k}^{(1)}x^{k}. (38)

The length of the expansion was chosen to be Nf​i​t=11subscript𝑁𝑓𝑖𝑡11N_{fit}=11 in each interval both for lasubscript𝑙𝑎l_{a} and lbsubscript𝑙𝑏l_{b}.

For x>x0≈36𝑥subscript𝑥036x>x_{0}\approx 36 the method described above needs to be slightly modified. This is the point where the critical line crosses l=32𝑙32l=32. Therefore, for x>x0𝑥subscript𝑥0x>x_{0} all Jl​(x)subscript𝐽𝑙𝑥J_{l}(x) with l≤32𝑙32l\leq 32 are positive, and it is sufficient to evaluate J32​(x)subscript𝐽32𝑥J_{32}(x) by fitting and carry out the recursion (35) downward. We used the following fitting function

∑k=0Nf​i​t′ck(2)​xk+1x81/2​∑k=0Nf​i​t′ck(3)​xk,superscriptsubscript𝑘0superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑓𝑖𝑡′superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑘2superscript𝑥𝑘1superscript𝑥812superscriptsubscript𝑘0superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑓𝑖𝑡′superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑘3superscript𝑥𝑘\displaystyle\sum_{k=0}^{N_{fit}^{\prime}}c_{k}^{(2)}x^{k}+\frac{1}{x^{81/2}}\sum_{k=0}^{N_{fit}^{\prime}}c_{k}^{(3)}x^{k}, (39)

with Nf​i​t′=9superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑓𝑖𝑡′9N_{fit}^{\prime}=9. The prefactor in the second term of this expression comes from the asymptotic expansion of Jlsubscript𝐽𝑙J_{l} which will be introduced in the next paragraph.

Finally, for x>xasym𝑥subscript𝑥asymx>x_{\mbox{\scriptsize asym}} we use large-x𝑥x asymptotic expansion of the Jl​(x)subscript𝐽𝑙𝑥J_{l}(x) functions. For l=0𝑙0l=0 the necessary expression was given in Ref. kpisz09

J0​(x)=π2​x3/2​∑k=0(2​k+1)!!2k​x−k,subscript𝐽0𝑥𝜋2superscript𝑥32subscript𝑘0double-factorial2𝑘1superscript2𝑘superscript𝑥𝑘\displaystyle J_{0}(x)=\frac{\sqrt{\pi}}{2x^{3/2}}\sum_{k=0}\frac{(2k+1)!!}{2^{k}}x^{-k}, (40)

and for larger l𝑙l the corresponding formulae can be obtained by noting that Jl​(x)=−∂xJl−1​(x)subscript𝐽𝑙𝑥subscript𝑥subscript𝐽𝑙1𝑥J_{l}(x)=-\partial_{x}J_{l-1}(x). The value of xasymsubscript𝑥asymx_{\mbox{\scriptsize asym}} was set to 125125125 after some numerical experimentation. Under these conditions the summation converges to the machine precision after at most 303030 terms. In general, the rate of convergence improves with increasing x𝑥x and thus the expansion (40) is able to handle arbitrarily large values of x>xasym𝑥subscript𝑥asymx>x_{\mbox{\scriptsize asym}}. Moreover, all terms in Eq. (40) are positive and thus no loss of digits in the summation is possible. This observation remains valid for l>0𝑙0l>0.

To sum up, the integrals Jl​(x)subscript𝐽𝑙𝑥J_{l}(x) are calculated with a union of three algorithms, involving polynomial fitting, recursion relations and asymptotic expansion. We note that the efficiency of the resulting code is only somewhat worse than for the aforementioned Boys function. A C++ implementation of the methods described in this section can be obtained upon request.

III Basis set convergence issue

Most of the ab initio methods used nowadays in the electronic structure theory rely on a basis set for expansion of the exact wavefunction. Consequently, observables obtained with a (necessarily finite) basis set suffer from the basis set incompleteness error. To allow for a meaningful comparison with the experimental data this error should be estimated and minimised, if possible.

One of the prominent techniques applied to remove a bulk fraction of the basis set incompleteness error is the extrapolation towards the exact theoretical value. However, to ensure that such a procedure is reliable one typically requires some information on how the calculated values converge towards the exact result as a function of the basis set size. For example, it was shown by Hill hill85 that the nonrelativistic energy converges as L−3superscript𝐿3L^{-3}, where L𝐿L is the largest angular momentum present in the basis set. It can be shown that some relativistic corrections converge even slower, as L−1superscript𝐿1L^{-1}. This was numerically observed in Refs. ottschofski97 ; halkier00 and later proved by Kutzelnigg kutz08 . In this case the values calculated with a finite basis set can be in error of tens of percents and extrapolation is necessary to arrive at a reliable result.

Concerning the Araki-Sucher correction, it has never been assessed thus far how the results obtained with finite basis sets converge as a function of the largest angular momentum included. To answer this question we consider the ground state of the helium atom as a model system where a strict asymptotic result can be obtained. Further in the paper we show numerically that the main conclusions are valid also for many-electron many-centre systems. This allows for a reliable extrapolation towards the complete basis set limit, dramatically improving the final results.

III.1 Definitions and notation

We consider the ground 11S state of the helium atom with the exact wavefunction given by Ψ​(𝐫1,𝐫2)Ψsubscript𝐫1subscript𝐫2\Psi(\mathbf{r}_{1},\mathbf{r}_{2}), where 𝐫isubscript𝐫𝑖\mathbf{r}_{i} are the positions of the electrons and 𝐫12=𝐫1−𝐫2subscript𝐫12subscript𝐫1subscript𝐫2\mathbf{r}_{12}=\mathbf{r}_{1}-\mathbf{r}_{2}. The corresponding wavefunction can be represented as

Ψ​(𝐫1,𝐫2)=∑l=0∞Ψl​(r1,r2)​Pl​(cos⁡θ12),Ψsubscript𝐫1subscript𝐫2superscriptsubscript𝑙0subscriptΨ𝑙subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟2subscript𝑃𝑙subscript𝜃12\displaystyle\Psi(\mathbf{r}_{1},\mathbf{r}_{2})=\sum_{l=0}^{\infty}\Psi_{l}(r_{1},r_{2})P_{l}(\cos\theta_{12}), (41)

where ri=|𝐫i|subscript𝑟𝑖subscript𝐫𝑖r_{i}=|\mathbf{r}_{i}|, Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l} are the Legendre polynomials, and θ12subscript𝜃12\theta_{12} is the angle between vectors 𝐫1subscript𝐫1\mathbf{r}_{1}, 𝐫2subscript𝐫2\mathbf{r}_{2}. The above expression is dubbed the partial wave expansion (PWE) by many authors and we shall follow this nomenclature for the wavefunctions and operators.

It is natural to define a family of approximants to the exact wavefunction by truncating Eq. (41) at a given L𝐿L, i.e.

ΨL​(𝐫1,𝐫2)=∑l=0LΨl​(r1,r2)​Pl​(cos⁡θ12).subscriptΨ𝐿subscript𝐫1subscript𝐫2superscriptsubscript𝑙0𝐿subscriptΨ𝑙subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟2subscript𝑃𝑙subscript𝜃12\displaystyle\Psi_{L}(\mathbf{r}_{1},\mathbf{r}_{2})=\sum_{l=0}^{L}\Psi_{l}(r_{1},r_{2})P_{l}(\cos\theta_{12}). (42)

The Araki-Sucher correction can be than approximated as the a→0→𝑎0a\rightarrow 0 limit of the following expectation values

⟨P^a​(ri​j−3)⟩L=⟨ΨL|P^a​(ri​j−3)|ΨL⟩/⟨ΨL|ΨL⟩.subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscript^𝑃𝑎superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑗3𝐿quantum-operator-productsubscriptΨ𝐿subscript^𝑃𝑎superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑗3subscriptΨ𝐿inner-productsubscriptΨ𝐿subscriptΨ𝐿\displaystyle\langle\hat{P}_{a}(r_{ij}^{-3})\rangle_{L}=\langle\Psi_{L}|\hat{P}_{a}(r_{ij}^{-3})|\Psi_{L}\rangle/\langle\Psi_{L}|\Psi_{L}\rangle. (43)

Obviously, in the infinite L𝐿L limit this series converges to the exact value, ⟨P^a​(ri​j−3)⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript^𝑃𝑎superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑗3\langle\hat{P}_{a}(r_{ij}^{-3})\rangle. Therefore, we may consider the error

ϵL​(a)=⟨P^a​(ri​j−3)⟩−⟨P^a​(ri​j−3)⟩Lsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝐿𝑎delimited-⟨⟩subscript^𝑃𝑎superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑗3subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscript^𝑃𝑎superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑗3𝐿\displaystyle\epsilon_{L}(a)=\langle\hat{P}_{a}(r_{ij}^{-3})\rangle-\langle\hat{P}_{a}(r_{ij}^{-3})\rangle_{L} (44)

as a function of L𝐿L and ask what is the asymptotic form of ϵL​(a)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝐿𝑎\epsilon_{L}(a) at large L𝐿L. After taking the a→0→𝑎0a\rightarrow 0 limit one recovers the actual result for the Araki-Sucher correction. This is only a precise mathematical restatement of the intuitive picture presented at the beginning of this section.

All derivations presented further rely on the seminal work of Hill and the methods introduced therein hill85 . The original presentation of Hill relies on a chain of postulates which are extremely difficult to prove strictly but are nonetheless very physically sound and hard to deny (especially in the face of ample numerical evidence). First, the denominator in Eq. (43) can be replaced by unity as it converges much faster than the numerator and does not contribute in the leading order. Second, for large L𝐿L the dominant contribution to the integral in Eq. (43) comes from the region around the electrons coalescence points. The famous Kato cusp condition kato57 teaches us that in this regime the exact wavefunction behaves as

Ψ​(𝐫1,𝐫2)=Ψ​(r,r,0)​(1+12​r12)+𝒪​(r122),Ψsubscript𝐫1subscript𝐫2Ψ𝑟𝑟0112subscript𝑟12𝒪superscriptsubscript𝑟122\displaystyle\Psi(\mathbf{r}_{1},\mathbf{r}_{2})=\Psi(r,r,0)\left(1+\frac{1}{2}r_{12}\right)+\mathcal{O}\big{(}r_{12}^{2}\big{)}, (45)

where Ψ​(r,r,0)Ψ𝑟𝑟0\Psi(r,r,0) is the value of the exact wavefunction at r12=0subscript𝑟120r_{12}=0. By using these assumptions modulus square of the wavefunction present is rewritten as

|Ψ​(𝐫1,𝐫2)|2=|Ψ​(r,r,0)|2​(1+r12)+𝒪​(r122).superscriptΨsubscript𝐫1subscript𝐫22superscriptΨ𝑟𝑟021subscript𝑟12𝒪superscriptsubscript𝑟122\displaystyle|\Psi(\mathbf{r}_{1},\mathbf{r}_{2})|^{2}=|\Psi(r,r,0)|^{2}\left(1+r_{12}\right)+\mathcal{O}\big{(}r_{12}^{2}\big{)}. (46)

Finally, let us recall PWE for r12subscript𝑟12r_{12}

r12subscript𝑟12\displaystyle r_{12} =∑l=0∞{r12}l​Pl​(cos⁡θ12),absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑙0subscriptsubscript𝑟12𝑙subscript𝑃𝑙subscript𝜃12\displaystyle=\sum_{l=0}^{\infty}\{r_{12}\}_{l}\,P_{l}(\cos\theta_{12}), (47)
{r12}lsubscriptsubscript𝑟12𝑙\displaystyle\{r_{12}\}_{l} =12​l+3​r<l+2r>l+1−12​l−1​r<lr>l−1,absent12𝑙3superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑙2superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑙112𝑙1superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑙superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑙1\displaystyle=\frac{1}{2l+3}\frac{r_{<}^{l+2}}{r_{>}^{l+1}}-\frac{1}{2l-1}\frac{r_{<}^{l}}{r_{>}^{l-1}}, (48)

where r<=min⁡(r1,r2)subscript𝑟subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟2r_{<}=\min(r_{1},r_{2}), r>=max⁡(r1,r2)subscript𝑟subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟2r_{>}=\max(r_{1},r_{2}). This expression is closely related to the well-known Laplace expansion of the potential.

where additionally some higher-order terms in 1/n1𝑛1/n have been neglected.

In′′​(a)=1a​∫0∞𝑑r>​∫0r>𝑑r<​|Ψ​(r>,r>,0)|2×θ​(a−r>+r<)​θ​(r>+r<−a)×Pn​(r>2+r<22​r>​r<)​[r<n+3​r>−n2​n+3−r<n+1​r>n−22​n−1].superscriptsubscript𝐼𝑛′′𝑎1𝑎superscriptsubscript0differential-dsubscript𝑟superscriptsubscript0subscript𝑟differential-dsubscript𝑟superscriptΨsubscript𝑟subscript𝑟02𝜃𝑎subscript𝑟subscript𝑟𝜃subscript𝑟subscript𝑟𝑎subscript𝑃𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑟2superscriptsubscript𝑟22subscript𝑟subscript𝑟delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑛3superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑛2𝑛3superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑛22𝑛1\displaystyle\begin{split}&I_{n}^{\prime\prime}(a)=\frac{1}{a}\int_{0}^{\infty}dr_{>}\int_{0}^{r_{>}}dr_{<}\,|\Psi(r_{>},r_{>},0)|^{2}\\ &\times\,\theta(a-r_{>}+r_{<})\,\theta(r_{>}+r_{<}-a)\\ &\times P_{n}\left(\frac{r_{>}^{2}+r_{<}^{2}}{2r_{>}r_{<}}\right)\left[\frac{r_{<}^{n+3}\,r_{>}^{-n}}{2n+3}-\frac{r_{<}^{n+1}\,r_{>}^{n-2}}{2n-1}\right].\end{split} (59)

By the virtues of the θ𝜃\theta function the integral can be rewritten to the form

1a​∫0∞𝑑r>​∫0r>𝑑r<​θ​(a−r>+r<)×θ(r>+r<−a)…=1a[∫a/2adr>∫a−r>r>dr<+∫a∞dr>∫r>−ar>dr<…]1𝑎superscriptsubscript0differential-dsubscript𝑟superscriptsubscript0subscript𝑟differential-dsubscript𝑟𝜃𝑎subscript𝑟subscript𝑟𝜃subscript𝑟subscript𝑟𝑎…1𝑎delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑎2𝑎𝑑subscript𝑟superscriptsubscript𝑎subscript𝑟subscript𝑟𝑑subscript𝑟superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑑subscript𝑟superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑟𝑎subscript𝑟𝑑subscript𝑟…\displaystyle\begin{split}&\frac{1}{a}\int_{0}^{\infty}dr_{>}\int_{0}^{r_{>}}dr_{<}\,\theta(a-r_{>}+r_{<})\\ &\times\theta(r_{>}+r_{<}-a)\,\ldots=\frac{1}{a}\bigg{[}\int_{a/2}^{a}dr_{>}\int_{a-r_{>}}^{r_{>}}dr_{<}\\ &+\int_{a}^{\infty}dr_{>}\int_{r_{>}-a}^{r_{>}}dr_{<}\,\ldots\bigg{]}\end{split} (60)

It turns out that in our case the first integral gives zero contribution (in the small a𝑎a limit). The inner integral of the second component can be expanded as a powers series in a𝑎a. The first term vanishes and only the second (i.e., proportional to a𝑎a) has to be retained giving

∫r>−ar>𝑑r<​Pn​(r>2+r<22​r>​r<)​[r<n+3​r>−n2​n+3−r<n+1​r>n−22​n−1]=a⋅Pn​(r>2+r<22​r>​r<)​[r<n+3​r>−n2​n+3−r<n+1​r>n−22​n−1]|r<=r>=a⋅−4​r>3(2​n−1)​(2​n+3)+𝒪​(a2).superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑟𝑎subscript𝑟differential-dsubscript𝑟subscript𝑃𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑟2superscriptsubscript𝑟22subscript𝑟subscript𝑟delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑛3superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑛2𝑛3superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑛22𝑛1evaluated-at⋅𝑎subscript𝑃𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑟2superscriptsubscript𝑟22subscript𝑟subscript𝑟delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑛3superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑛2𝑛3superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑛22𝑛1subscript𝑟subscript𝑟⋅𝑎4superscriptsubscript𝑟32𝑛12𝑛3𝒪superscript𝑎2\displaystyle\begin{split}&\int_{r_{>}-a}^{r_{>}}dr_{<}\,P_{n}\left(\frac{r_{>}^{2}+r_{<}^{2}}{2r_{>}r_{<}}\right)\left[\frac{r_{<}^{n+3}\,r_{>}^{-n}}{2n+3}-\frac{r_{<}^{n+1}\,r_{>}^{n-2}}{2n-1}\right]=\\ &a\cdot P_{n}\left(\frac{r_{>}^{2}+r_{<}^{2}}{2r_{>}r_{<}}\right)\left[\frac{r_{<}^{n+3}\,r_{>}^{-n}}{2n+3}-\frac{r_{<}^{n+1}\,r_{>}^{n-2}}{2n-1}\right]\bigg{|}_{r_{<}=\,r_{>}}=\\ &a\cdot\frac{-4\,r_{>}^{3}}{(2n-1)(2n+3)}+\mathcal{O}\left(a^{2}\right).\end{split} (61)

Upon reinserting into Eq. (59) and rearranging one obtains

In′′​(a)=−4(2​n−1)​(2​n+3)​∫0∞𝑑r>​r>3×|Ψ​(r>,r>,0)|2+𝒪​(a).superscriptsubscript𝐼𝑛′′𝑎42𝑛12𝑛3superscriptsubscript0differential-dsubscript𝑟superscriptsubscript𝑟3superscriptΨsubscript𝑟subscript𝑟02𝒪𝑎\displaystyle\begin{split}I_{n}^{\prime\prime}(a)&=\frac{-4}{(2n-1)(2n+3)}\int_{0}^{\infty}dr_{>}\,r_{>}^{3}\\ &\times|\Psi(r_{>},r_{>},0)|^{2}+\mathcal{O}\left(a\right).\end{split} (62)

The last integral In′′′​(a)superscriptsubscript𝐼𝑛′′′𝑎I_{n}^{\prime\prime\prime}(a) is the simplest to evaluate. One inserts Eq. (54) into Eq. (56) and executes the Dirac delta to arrive at

In′′′​(a)=−4​(γ+ln⁡a)(2​n−1)​(2​n+3)×∫0∞dr>r>3|Ψ(r>,r>,0)|2,superscriptsubscript𝐼𝑛′′′𝑎4𝛾𝑎2𝑛12𝑛3superscriptsubscript0𝑑subscript𝑟superscriptsubscript𝑟3superscriptΨsubscript𝑟subscript𝑟02\displaystyle\begin{split}I_{n}^{\prime\prime\prime}(a)&=-\frac{4(\gamma+\ln a)}{(2n-1)(2n+3)}\\ &\times\int_{0}^{\infty}dr_{>}\,r_{>}^{3}\,|\Psi(r_{>},r_{>},0)|^{2},\end{split} (63)

without invoking any approximations. Finally, we add up the three integrals evaluated above

In(a)=14​π21(2​n−1)​(2​n+3)×[(ln⁡(2​n+3)−32)​𝒥3−𝒥ln]+𝒪​(a),subscript𝐼𝑛𝑎14superscript𝜋212𝑛12𝑛3delimited-[]2𝑛332subscript𝒥3subscript𝒥𝒪𝑎\displaystyle\begin{split}&I_{n}(a)=\frac{1}{4\pi^{2}}\frac{1}{(2n-1)(2n+3)}\times\\ &\bigg{[}\left(\ln\left(2n+3\right)-\frac{3}{2}\right)\mathcal{J}_{3}-\mathcal{J}_{\ln}\bigg{]}+\mathcal{O}\left(a\right),\end{split} (64)

where

𝒥3=16​π2​∫0∞𝑑r​r3​|Ψ​(r,r,0)|2,subscript𝒥316superscript𝜋2superscriptsubscript0differential-d𝑟superscript𝑟3superscriptΨ𝑟𝑟02\displaystyle\mathcal{J}_{3}=16\pi^{2}\int_{0}^{\infty}dr\,r^{3}\,|\Psi(r,r,0)|^{2}, (65)
𝒥ln=16​π2​∫0∞𝑑r​r3​ln⁡r​|Ψ​(r,r,0)|2.subscript𝒥16superscript𝜋2superscriptsubscript0differential-d𝑟superscript𝑟3𝑟superscriptΨ𝑟𝑟02\displaystyle\mathcal{J}_{\ln}=16\pi^{2}\int_{0}^{\infty}dr\,r^{3}\,\ln r\,|\Psi(r,r,0)|^{2}. (66)

One can see that in the final expression all logarithmic singularities cancel out. Therefore, we can now take the limit a→0→𝑎0a\rightarrow 0 removing all higher-order terms in a𝑎a.

Let us now return to the formula for the error, Eq. (55) at a=0𝑎0a=0. Making use of Eq. (LABEL:finali) and after some algebra the result can be written as

ϵL​(0)=4​𝒥3​∑n=L+1∞ln⁡(2​n+3)(2​n−1)​(2​n+3)−4​(32​𝒥3+𝒥ln)​∑n=L+1∞1(2​n−1)​(2​n+3).subscriptitalic-ϵ𝐿04subscript𝒥3superscriptsubscript𝑛𝐿12𝑛32𝑛12𝑛3432subscript𝒥3subscript𝒥superscriptsubscript𝑛𝐿112𝑛12𝑛3\displaystyle\begin{split}&\epsilon_{L}(0)=4\mathcal{J}_{3}\sum_{n=L+1}^{\infty}\frac{\ln\left(2n+3\right)}{(2n-1)(2n+3)}\\ &-4\left(\frac{3}{2}\mathcal{J}_{3}+\mathcal{J}_{\ln}\right)\sum_{n=L+1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{(2n-1)(2n+3)}.\end{split} (67)

The first infinite sum is nontrivial to evaluate, but we can utilise the Euler-Maclaurin resummation formula to get the large-L𝐿L asymptotics. This gives the leading-order expressions and their error estimates

∑n=L+1∞ln⁡(2​n+3)(2​n−1)​(2​n+3)=1+ln⁡2​L4​L+𝒪​(ln⁡LL2),superscriptsubscript𝑛𝐿12𝑛32𝑛12𝑛312𝐿4𝐿𝒪𝐿superscript𝐿2\displaystyle\sum_{n=L+1}^{\infty}\frac{\ln\left(2n+3\right)}{(2n-1)(2n+3)}=\frac{1+\ln 2L}{4L}+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\ln L}{L^{2}}\right), (68)
∑n=L+1∞1(2​n−1)​(2​n+3)=14​L+𝒪​(L−2).superscriptsubscript𝑛𝐿112𝑛12𝑛314𝐿𝒪superscript𝐿2\displaystyle\sum_{n=L+1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{(2n-1)(2n+3)}=\frac{1}{4L}+\mathcal{O}\left(L^{-2}\right). (69)

Finally, we rewrite the error formula as

ϵL​(0)=𝒥3​ln⁡2​LL−1L​(𝒥ln+12​𝒥3)+𝒪​(ln⁡LL2),subscriptitalic-ϵ𝐿0subscript𝒥32𝐿𝐿1𝐿subscript𝒥12subscript𝒥3𝒪𝐿superscript𝐿2\displaystyle\epsilon_{L}(0)=\mathcal{J}_{3}\frac{\ln 2L}{L}-\frac{1}{L}\Big{(}\mathcal{J}_{\ln}+\frac{1}{2}\mathcal{J}_{3}\Big{)}+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\ln L}{L^{2}}\right), (70)

which indicates a very slow, i.e., logarithmic convergence of the Araki-Sucher correction towards the exact value. In fact, the convergence rate is even slower than for the aforementioned relativistic corrections kutz08 . Nevertheless, the above formula gives precise information on how the values from the finite basis sets should be extrapolated.

IV Numerical results

IV.1 Benchmark calculations

To verify that the method of calculation of the matrix elements of the Araki-Sucher distribution and the extrapolation scheme (70) are both valid we performed calculations for several systems where reference values of this quantity are known to a sufficient accuracy. The includes the helium atom (He), lithium atom (Li) and its cation (Li+), beryllium atom (Be) and its cation (Be+), and the hydrogen molecule (H2). Expectation values of the Araki-Sucher distribution were computed by using the finite-field approach. Suitable values of the displacement parameter were found individually for each system by trial-and-error. Typically, a value of about 10−5superscript10510^{-5} was optimal. For the two- and three-electron systems (He, Li+, H2, Li, Be+) we used the full CI method to solve the electronic Schrödinger equation (this method is exact in the complete basis set limit). For larger systems we employed the CCSD(T) method ragha89 ; piecuch02 . All electronic structure calculations reported in this work were performed with help of a locally modified version of the Gamess program package gamess1 ; gamess2 . For the helium atom we used the customised basis sets developed by Cencek et al. cencek12 . For the hydrogen molecule, lithium and beryllium (both neutral atoms and cations) the standard basis sets developed in Refs. dunning89 ; prascher11 were employed.

In Table 1 we show results for the calculations for the helium atom. One can see a very slow convergence of the results with the size of the basis set. To overcome this difficulty we applied a two-point extrapolation formula, Eq. (70). Note that in the present case we do not extrapolate with respect to the maximal angular momentum present in the basis (L𝐿L) but rather with respect to the so-called cardinal number (X𝑋X) dunning89 . This does not change the asymptotic formula (70) but changes values of the numerical coefficients in the expansion. Therefore, we do not attempt to compare the values obtained by fitting with the analytic results given by Eqs. (65) and (66). Nonetheless, the quality of the extrapolation is very good. Extrapolation from the basis sets X=3,…,6𝑋3…6X=3,\ldots,6 reduces the error from about 30% to less than 1.5% (cf. Table 1). One can safely say that the extrapolation is mandatory to obtain results of any reasonable quality.

Let us now pass to the calculations for the hydrogen molecule, H2. We calculated the Araki-Sucher correction for several internuclear distances and compared them with more accurate values given by Piszczatowski et al. kpisz09 and by Stanke et al. stanke17 obtained with the explicitly correlated Gaussian wavefunctions. Our extrapolated results are given in Table 2 and compared with the two sets of reference values. One can see a reasonable agreement between the present results and Refs. stanke17 ; kpisz09 . The biggest absolute deviation from the values of Piszczatowski et al. kpisz09 is about 4%. This is only slightly larger than for the helium atom. This error increase can be (at least partially) attributed to the fact that a larger d7Z basis set was used for helium atom while calculations for the hydrogen molecule were restricted to the d6Z basis.

Finally, in Table 3 we show results of the calculations for the lithium and beryllium atoms as well as the corresponding cations. Our extrapolated values are compared with the reference data taken from the papers of Frolov et al. frolov15 ; frolov14 and Pachucki et al. pachucki04b ; puchalski08 . The errors are consistently within the range of 1−-2%. Only for the lithium cation the accuracy is slightly worse (≈\approx\,3%) but this is probably accidental. We can also check how well relative differences are reproduced in our method. To this end, we calculate contributions of the Araki-Sucher term to the ionisation energies of the lithium and beryllium atoms and compare the results with Refs. pachucki04b ; puchalski08 . In both cases we find a remarkable agreement within approx. 1% of the total value.

To sum up, the method of calculating the Araki-Sucher correction proposed here is fundamentally valid and useful in practice. By comparing our results with the reference data available in the literature for several few-body systems we conclude that it is capable of reaching an accuracy of a few percents or better. This is true provided that sufficiently large basis sets and accurate electronic structure methods are employed. Moreover, extrapolation to the complete basis set limit must be performed in every case. The theoretically derived leading-order formula (70) is very efficient in this respect.

IV.2 Results for many-electron systems

The biggest advantage of the method proposed here is that it can be applied to systems much larger than studied previously. This includes not only many-electron atoms, but also diatomic and even polyatomic molecules. To illustrate this we performed calculations for several many-body systems - the magnesium atom (Mg) and its ion (Mg+) and the argon atom (Ar) and its dimer (Ar2). In the case of Mg and Mg+ we employed the IP-EOM-CCSD-3A method gour05 ; gour06 and the basis sets “aug-cc-pwCVX“ reported in Ref. prascher11 . For the Ar and Ar2 systems we used the CCSD(T) method and the basis sets “disp-XZ+2/AE” developed by Patkowski and Szalewicz patkowski10 specifically for accurate description of the argon dimer. The results are shown in Table 4. Overall, the rate of convergence of the values obtained in finite basis sets is similar as for the helium atom which validates the extrapolation formula (70) for many-electron systems. We can estimate that the accuracy of the results shown in Table 4 is not worse than 5%.

With the help of the results from Table 4 one can also calculate the contribution of the Araki-Sucher correction to the ionisation energy of the magnesium atom and interaction energy the argon dimer. The former quantity is approximately equal to −-0.02 cm-1 (the negative sign indicates that this correction decreases the ionisation energy). While this value seems to be very small we note that it is of the same order of magnitude as the present-day experimental uncertainty in the measurement of the ionisation energy of the magnesium atom, 0.03 cm-1 martin80 ; chang87 ; kaufman91 . For the argon dimer we calculate that the contribution to the interaction energy of the Araki-Sucher term is equal to 0.02 cm-1. Again, this value has to be put into context. The total interaction energy of the argon dimer is approximately 99 cm-1. Therefore, while the Araki-Sucher contribution is small on the absolute scale, it becomes non-negligible in relation to other subtle effects. Moreover, the theoretical accuracy attainable for the argon dimer at present patkowski10 ; slavicek03 ; patkowski05 is already quite close to the level where the QED effects come into play.

V Conclusions

In the present work we have put forward a general scheme to calculate the Araki-Sucher correction for many-electron systems. Several obstacles had to be removed to accomplish this goal. First, the complicated two-electron integrals involving the Araki-Sucher distribution have been solved with help of the McMurchie-Davidson technique (within the Gaussian-type orbitals basis set). It has been shown that they can be expressed through a family of one-dimensional integrals. Recursive and numerically stable computation of the latter integrals has been discussed in details.

Second, the issue of convergence of the results with respect to the size of the basis set has been considered. We have demonstrated a slow convergence pattern (ln⁡2​L/L2𝐿𝐿\ln 2L/L in the leading order) towards the complete basis set limit. This result has been verified by comparing with reference data for the helium atom. With the analytic information about the convergence at hand, extrapolations have been used to improve the accuracy of the results. The accuracy of about 1% has been achieved in this case.

To confirm the validity of the proposed approach we have performed calculations for several few- and many-electron systems. First, we have concentrated on small systems (e.g., few-electron atoms, hydrogen molecule) for which accurate reference values are available in the literature. A consistent accuracy of few percents have been obtained and the molecular results are only slightly less accurate than the atoms. Next, we have moved on to many-electron systems. We have estimated the contribution of the Araki-Sucher correction to the ionisation energy of the magnesium atom and interaction energy of the argon dimer. The final values of the Araki-Sucher correction are comparable to the present day experimental uncertainties of the measurements.

which is sufficient for the present purposes. Finally, to arrive at Eqs. (51)-(54) from the main text one has to gather Eqs. (74), (76), (77), (78), and (79) and rearrange.
